comment: ANTH 2220. She is a great professor and obviously loves what she does but she treats this 2000 course harder than her 4000 course. Attendance isnt mandatory  but you should go because her PowerPoint aren't helpful. She has in class presentations group projects and more homework than any class I've ever been in. Her test are graded harshly. Beware.
rating_tags: Tough grader--Get ready to read--Lots of homework

comment: She structures her quizzes and tests and assugments like they're upper level, everyone did poorly on her second exam and she refused to curve it
Dr. Smith is a tough and strict professor, yet she continues to show that she cares about you and your grades and is willing to help you.

This was honestly the hardest course I had ever taken from a difficulty perspective. I had to study the hardest I have ever studied in my academic career. However, this was also one of the most enjoyable classes I've ever taken. So long as you work hard, study hard, and have a passion for anthropology, you will enjoy this class.

You HAVE to attend class, her PowerPoints are posted online but only contain visuals. If you want any notes from class you have to be there to take them yourself. The textbook is heavily used and you will have to do all the assigned reading to fully understand the course. Essays are graded heavily but she is very knowledgable and kind.
rating_tags: Tough grader--Participation matters--Graded by few things

comment: Shes gives a lot of papers which are a minimum of 4 pages nothing less ! Shes a tough grader and will definitely ruin your confidence and make you feel like you dont know you are talking about.
rating_tags: Tough grader--So many papers--Lots of homework

comment: She is a nice professor and for the most part the class was easy. Lectures were boring and most info on tests was from what she said and the readings. Easy to get an A on all assignments however, tests were difficult and are all written response.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Graded by few things

comment: Dr. Smith is an awesome professor who really cares about the material being taught. She presents a lot of her own research in the lectures, and you know immediately that she's an expert in her field. Her tests aren't tough if you just write what you know about a topic, and the same goes for her papers, She just wants to see that you comprehend her.

Dr. Smith was a great professor. I liked how her lectures were not reiterations of the textbook chapters assigned, but rather served as supplementary information. This class is very discussion-based and casual. To me her tests are easy, but it's all written response so you have to be comfortable with the material discussed and read.
rating_tags: Gives good feedback--Clear grading criteria--Amazing lectures

comment: Professor Smith has a lot of papers that you must write. Although her grading system is very complex and doesn't really seem to make sense. She is very heavy on punctuation. I would take her class in person instead of online, she is an easy A. Her quiz are no lockdown browsers.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--So many papers--Tough grader

comment: As easy as anthropology should be, she was way too strict on grading papers. Unclear feedback along with harsh deductions for the SMALLEST errors. DNR
rating_tags: Lots of homework--Get ready to read--Lecture heavy

comment: Legit the hardest class I have ever had the misfortune of taking. Not a bad professor to speak to, she is very nice. However, this doesn't apply when grading. You will be left wondering why you even spent time and effort on an assignment (each of which take a bare minimum of one hour to complete) only to get docked more than half your grade.

ANTH 1102: Dr. Smith is a nice professor and respects her students when you communicate correctly. There is A LOT of writing between discussions and assignments. There is a mandatory textbook that is pretty cheap electronically. Her quizzes are very short and don't last long ... know the material before you take the quizzes!
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Clear grading criteria--So many papers

comment: I was Susan's student back when she was teaching an intro to Archaeology at Indiana University where she received her PhD. During that time I struck up a friendship with her and it was through this friendship and her inspirational stories that eventually led me on to my BA in Anthropology and eventual MFA in Fine Arts. A fantastic educator!
rating_tags: Gives good feedback--Participation matters--BEWARE OF POP QUIZZES

comment: Dr. Smith is wonderful. She is very nice and understanding and very willing to help. Her tests were all ESSAY and IDENTIFICATIONS though so you HAVE to study for them or you will not do well. Use examples from the lectures on the tests! One group presentation at the end of the semester. This was a hybrid class. only met 1 day/week. rest was online

This is my 2nd semester with Dr. Smith; I would take any physical anthropology class with her. I think she is one of the most dedicated, helpful, and responsive professors at KSU. She has a wonderful way of presenting material and is interested in advancing your education. Put in the effort and you won't regret it.

She is a great teacher. She obviously loves what she does & is very informed about her subject of study. If u simply attend class, participate in discussions, and study a small amount for her tests, u will do well.

I took this as a Maymester. Very fast paced. The grading scale makes it so even if you fail both tests, and long as you do all the other assignments and participate in class discussions, you WILL pass with at least a C. She's funny and makes the class very interesting. You can she's very passionate about the subject!
This class was so much fun, very informative. The fast pace of Maymester made it easy. After taking this course, I have decided to change my second major from English to Anthro.
WONDERFUL!!!!!  Seriously, her goal is to give you an OVERVIEW... just as the course is supposed to do.  There are several of us contemplating changing majors because of her!!!!!!!

one of the worst profs I've had at ksu.Has her favorites, its obvious.If you are boisterous and interrupt class to make stupid comments,I'm sure she'll love you.If you are serious and are trying to do well,she grades hard and discourages more with every grade.you have to turn in every "step" of a research paper.LAME all around,take only if required

Go to class and take notes, and read ALL directions on tests and you will do fine! Fun class, and fun teacher! Lots of fun discussions. One group project that was a major part of the grade. She even offered extra credit.
Information is not clear cut. Tests are harder than hell.

It is all about learning to her. She wants you to understand the topics discussed, wants students to be engaged. She gives you every opportunity to do well. Will let you rewrite your papers to address her critique. Her essay tests are stressful but once you are done you realize they are fair. Read the material and participate you will do well.

Great Professor.  I took her during may session 2006.  Participation made up most of your grade.  2 easy written assignments, 1 article to share with the class, and 2 exams (both which came from notes and vocabulary).  I am a science major, and I don't really get into topics like this, but she was so interesting. funny and caring. GREAT PROFESSSOR!

I loved this teacher. You can tell she loves her job. The class is easy but the test was little harder because the short answere section was so detailed. But when the class complained about the short answers, for the final, she let us write really easy 2~3 page paper instead and turn it in by the day of the final.
Nice teacher, really enjoys what she does. Okay tests but you definitely have to study for them. Her notes are the tests. Some short answer on tests. Overall, good class/teacher.
I LOVE THIS PROFFESOR SHE IS THE BEST PROFFESOR I HAVE EVER HAD AND IS VER INSPERATIONAL. YOU CAN TELL SHE LOVES WHAT SHE DOES. I HIGHLY RECOMENED HER!!
awesome professor

I had her for forensic anthropology. Before the class I was extremely interested in forensics, but now I just view the class as a bore.  We had to learn 306 bones in the body and different portions of each bone.  I found it to be too indepth for a beginning class. :(
